Treatment

Gastric lavage may be performed within 1 hour from ingestion or if large quantities were taken. Activated charcoal has no role in reducing the absorption of ethylene glycol.

In the Netherlands, ethanol therapy is used for treatment of ethylene glycol poisoning. Another drug, fomepizole, has also been recently approved for the same indication. Both ethanol and fomepizole have greater affinity to alcohol dehydrogenase than ethylene glycol, thereby inhibiting the conversion of ethylene glycol to glycoaldehyde. To date, no clinical trials have compared the use of one over the other, so the choice of treatment is dependent on the institution and on other secondary factors. The higher price and limited shelf life of fomepizole, given the relatively low incidence of ethylene glycol poisoning, make it a less common choice. In addition, many Dutch hospital pharmacies are able to perform rapid analysis of blood alcohol levels, which allow for precise calculation of the dosage of ethanol.

Parameters Ethanol Fomepizole
Affinity to ADH 100x greater than ethylene glycol 8000x greater than ethanol
Target levels of compound in blood Ethanol levels 1000-1500 mg/L Fomepizole levels > 0.8 mg/L
Indication Ethylene glycol concentration >200 mg/L
Metabolic acidosis (pH 7.2-7.3)
Dialysis		 Ethylene glycol concentration >200 mg/L
Metabolic acidosis (pH 7.2-7.3)
Dialysis
Administration Intravenous in 5% glucose Intravenous
Loading dose: 15 mg/kg in 100 mL 5% glucose solution or 0.9% NaCl in 30 to 45 minutes
Maintenance dose is guided by renal function, and should aim for blood ethylene glycol levels <100 mg/L

Hemodialysis is indicated when (1) blood ethylene glycol level is >500 mg/L; (2) vital signs rapidly deteriorate; (3) metabolic acidosis (pH 7.2 - 7.3) is present; (4) renal impairment is worsening; or (5) calcium oxalate crystals are present in urine. Doses of ethanol or fomepizole should be adjusted during dialysis. The goal of dialysis is resolution of metabolic acidosis, and blood ethylene glycol levels <100 mg/L.

Symptom control is usually achieved using the following protocol:

Symptom Treatment
Seizures 5-10 mg diazepam IV in 2-3 minutes as needed, may repeat after 10 minutes up to 30 mg. if seizures are persistent, may need to control Ca2+ and Mg2+ since these electrolytes can be scavenged by oxalate.
Acidosis Administer bicarbonate when blood pH is <7.2; and ensure hemodynamic stability
Metabolism Administration of pyridoxine and thiamine for 2 days to promote the conversion of glyoxylic acid and glycolic acid to less toxic metabolites
